metadata.case_name: D. R. Nim v. Union of India

facts.text: Appellant appointed to the U.P. Police Service as a result of a competitive examination held in 1938.
Appellant appointed officiating Superintendent of Police with effect from June 25, 1947, and continued to officiate till appointed to the Indian Police Service.
Appellant appointed to the Indian Police Service against the promotion quota of the Indian Police Service Cadre of Uttar Pradesh with effect from October 22, 1955.

Impugned order dated August 25, 1955, passed by the Government of India, Ministry of Home Affairs, deciding that State Civil Service Officers officiating prior to 19th May, 1951, but appointed to Indian Administrative Service after that date, be allowed benefit of continuous officiation from 19th May, 1951; same applied to State Police Officers promoted to Indian Police Service after 19th May, 1951.
Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi dismissed in limine the petition under Art. 226 filed by appellant on December 8, 1961.
Indian Police Service (Regulation of Seniority) Rules, 1954, issued by Central Government under All India Services Act, 1951.
Appellant's name included in the Select List of 1956.
Shri R. C. Dutt's letter No. 1/18/51-AIS dated 22nd June, 1951, prescribing procedure for fixation of seniority and year of allotment.
Date May 19, 1951, chosen as crucial date related to finalisation of Gradation List for I.A.S., extended to I.P.S.

Government decided in consultation with Ministry of Law that letter dated 25th August, 1955, not applicable to SCS/SPS officers appointed to IAS/IPS prior to Seniority Rules, 1954, if earlier continuous officiation approved.
In case of Shri C. S. Prasad, IPS officer of Bihar, decision taken to give benefit of full continuous officiation and revise year of allotment.
Appellant officiated continuously for eight years without reversion.

legal_issues.text: Whether the impugned order dated August 25, 1955, is contrary to law and Article 14 of the Constitution.
Whether the year of allotment of the appellant has been correctly determined under Rule 3 of the Indian Police Service (Regulation of Seniority) Rules, 1954.
Whether the selection of May 19, 1951, as a crucial date in the impugned order is arbitrary and irrational.
Whether the appellant's officiation was a purely temporary or local arrangement under Explanation 1 to Rule 3.

petitioner_arguments.text: Wrong year of allotment given by application of impugned order, which is void.
On proper construction of rules, entire period of officiation in senior post to be counted towards seniority.
Selection of May 19, 1951, as crucial date arbitrary and irrational.
Impugned order without legal authority and contrary to rules.
Officiation not temporary or local arrangement as it lasted eight years without reversion and when vacancies fell.

respondent_arguments.text: Impugned order determined year of allotment; period prior to May 19, 1951 excluded to avoid anomaly where rejected candidates get higher seniority over earlier selected ones.
Appellant's case does not fall under recent decision as appointed after Seniority Rules 1954 and impugned letter.
Appellant's continuous officiation was temporary or local arrangement due to paucity of officers; primarily those not selected earlier.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 3 is controlling for assignment of year of allotment; appellant falls under Rule 3(3)(b) as promoted after commencement; first proviso applies requiring ad hoc determination by Central Government.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Formula: year of allotment of junior-most competitive recruit who officiated continuously earlier than appellant.

court_reasoning.text: Period prior to inclusion in 1956 Select List must be approved by Central Government in consultation with Commission.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Second proviso divides officiation into pre and post Select List periods.

court_reasoning.text: Impugned order fixes artificial date May 19, 1951, irrelevant to IPS as it pertains to IAS Gradation List; arbitrary classification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot pick date arbitrarily; must consider individual facts.

court_reasoning.text: Central Government must consider approval of pre-1956 officiation ad hoc after relevant circumstances, not by blanket order.
Stop-gap arrangement cannot last eight years; no reversion shown; appointed when vacancies fell, negating temporary nature.

holdings.text: Impugned order dated August 25, 1955, contrary to Rule 3 of Seniority Rules as it fixes arbitrary date May 19, 1951.
Central Government must determine year of allotment ad hoc considering all relevant circumstances including approval of pre-Select List officiation.
Selection of May 19, 1951 arbitrary and irrational.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned order challenged as contrary to Art. 14; writ under Art. 226 dismissed by High Court.

statutes_cited.name: All India Services Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Central Government issued rules under this Act.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Police Service (Regulation of Seniority) Rules, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs assignment of year of allotment; impugned order held contrary.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Police Service (Recruitment) Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for promotion appointments and comparisons.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Police Service (Appointment by Promotion) Regulations

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; impugned order held invalid and arbitrary; Central Government directed to determine appellant's year of allotment afresh under Rule 3 considering relevant facts and approving pre-1956 officiation period.
outcome.relief_granted: Year of allotment to be fixed ad hoc by Central Government in consultation with State and Commission.

key_quotes.text: I would say that there is no arbitrariness in this matter and that this was done after consulting all concerned and after evolving a sound principle...
key_quotes.speaker: respondent
key_quotes.significance: Court disagreed, finding arbitrariness in date selection.

key_quotes.text: We agree with him in this respect [arbitrary and irrational selection of May 19, 1951].
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court accepts petitioner's contention on arbitrariness under Art. 14.

key_quotes.text: The Central Government cannot pick out a date from a hat and... say that a period prior to that date would not be deemed to be approved.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on invalidity of blanket artificial date.

key_quotes.text: Such a stop-gap arrangement cannot last for eight years and it has not been shown that the appellant was appointed temporarily in place of some persons as subsequently he has never been reverted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
